'We went through hell': Sudan's capital Khartoum slowly comes back to life
subhead: War in Sudan: A Trapped Nation (2/6). After serving as the civil war's frontline for two years, Khartoum was retaken by the official army in March. Since then, the city has been struggling to rise from its ashes.

subhead: In the face of Trump and his triumphant ethnonationalism, the regulatory parties – whether it be on artificial intelligence, environmental policy, financial capitalism or international relations – are remaining silent for now, notes Le Monde editorial writer Gilles Paris.

title: In China, a Ming dynasty painting donated to a major museum resurfaces at auction
subhead: A masterpiece from the Nanjing Museum, donated by the family of a renowned collector, recently appeared at an auction, reigniting debate over the management of public collections.

title: Dry January's lasting benefits win over more and more participants
subhead: The challenge, which involves taking a break from drinking alcohol for one month, brings numerous health benefits. As proof of its success, alcohol-free initiatives are gaining ground.

title: Kharkiv ends the year amid bombs and Christmas lights
subhead: Despite the ever-present sound of air-raid sirens, the city in eastern Ukraine decided to deck itself out in Christmas colors to recapture some festive spirit. Yet the semblance of normalcy remains difficult for some residents to fully embrace.

Iran's protests led by shopkeepers is shaking up the regime
subhead: The collapse of the rial currency deepens the economic struggles faced by retailers, who have taken to the streets in several major cities. Some universities in Tehran have also joined the mobilization, as economic grievances merge with increasingly political slogans.

title: Online gambling companies zero in on France's disadvantaged neighborhoods
subhead: Exposed to a flood of advertising, young men from urban areas have increasingly turned to online sports betting. This trend leads to addictive behaviors, now deemed 'a public health issue.'

title: In Brazil, love vibrates at the heart of society
subhead: Traditions around love have long spilled beyond the realm of intimacy to shape the social, political and even collective identity of the country, writes Le Monde's correspondent Bruno Meyerfeld in his final dispatch.
